newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Europe paper industry rejects U.S. call on tariffs.
newsitem.headline: Europe paper industry rejects U.S. call on tariffs.

text.p: The Confederation of European Paper Industries (CEPI) has rejected calls from the U.S. forest industry for faster tariff cuts on newsprint and other paper products.
CEPI said it had advised the European Commission and Trade Commissioner Sir Leon Brittan that it could not accept any further reductions apart from those already agreed.
"CEPI feel that the reductions given so far, and the timescale agreed, are more than sufficient to meet the further demands being made by the North Americans in tariffs," it said in a statement.
CEPI said increasing European exports to the U.S. market was not because of higher European tariffs.
"The reason for increasing imports into the United States is to do with the technical superiority of the product and not with tariffs," it said.

The American Forest & Paper Association (AF&PA) and the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association are pushing for action to accelerate tariff cuts at the first ministerial meeting of the World Trade Organisation in Singapore on December 9-13.
The Singapore conference is expected to review the Uruguay Round and set the pace for new trade talks due to begin in 1999.

AF&PA president Henson Moore told reporters last Thursday he wanted to see efforts made "to advance the demise of the paper tariffs that are in the Uruguay Round, to have them end on January 1, 1998."
This would be six years earlier than was agreed in the Uruguay Round trade pact in 1994.
The AF&PA says that European tariffs on paper products are much higher than in the United States, Canada or Japan.
According to AF&PA, some European tariffs are still at seven percent while most paper products enter the United States duty free.

CEPI said certain tariffs, including those on newsprint, were reduced and timescales shortened during talks on the enlargement of the European Union to bring in Sweden, Finland and Austria. -- Brussels newsroom +32 2 287 68 11
